item.title: Fallout Season 2 Finale Teases New Location And Something Big
item.content:encoded:
Fallout season twoâ€™s finale might not have paid off all the various story threads this season set up, but it did tease a location rarely seen in the games and featured the reveal of something big returning from Fallout 3 and Fallout 4. Spoilers below for the season in general and the finale episode in particular. If you havenâ€™t watched it yet and donâ€™t want to be spoiled, donâ€™t keep scrolling!

After two seasons of following the Ghoul as he searched for his family, Fallout season twoâ€™s finale finally brings him face to face withâ€¦their empty cryopods hidden deep in a secret Vault below Mr. Houseâ€™s Lucky 38 Casino. Dang. But inside his wifeâ€™s tube is a postcard for Colorado, giving him hope that his family is still alive in the midwestern state.

So off he goes on a new quest to hopefully find his wife and daughter after a heck of a 200 years. During the credits, a billboard reinforces the idea that next season will, at least partially, be set in Colorado. What do we know about Colorado in the Fallout universe, and what can we expect?

Colorado In The Fallout Universe

Colorado is a state that has been mentioned a few times in past games and Fallout media, but has rarely played a big role. It, like most of the rest of the United States in Fallout, was mostly wiped out by the nuclear bombs dropped during the Great War. Coloradoâ€™s biggest appearance in the games thus far happened in Fallout Tactics, a game that isnâ€™t wholly canon, but parts of it might be (itâ€™s weird). In that 2001 tactical turn-based RPG spin-off, we are introduced to Vault 0.

Vault 0 is set in an expanded version of the real-life Cheyenne Mountain Complex, a large underground U.S. military bunker designed to survive nuclear war and other massive attacks. Exactly what happens in Fallout Tactics isnâ€™t really important, but Vault 0 and the Cheyenne Mountain Complex could play a part in season three. We know the Enclave is still around, and it would make sense for them to hole up in something like that to hide away from the rest of the wasteland.

Interestingly, as pointed out by PC Gamer, in the lead-up to Fallout season one, Amazon posted an hour-long video about the opening of Vault 33. And during the stream, an announcer says this: â€œUnless youâ€™re the President of the United States or something like that, and you have a mountain in Colorado to go under and direct the events of the world.â€ And who did Cooper Howard run into in this season and hand off the Cold Fusion capsule to? The president. I suspect Vault 0 or a version of it will play a role in season three.

One other interesting thing to note about Colorado is that the original version of Fallout 3 that was being developed by Black Isle Studios before it was canceled was going to be partially set in Colorado. Fitting that Colorado will likely play a big role in season three of Amazonâ€™s Fallout show, given that it was previously featured in both the third Fallout game ever made (Tactics) and the original Fallout 3 (Project Van Buren).

That Other Big (Wink) Tease

After all the credits, Amazon included a post-credits teaser scene featuring Elder Cleric Quintus and Dane back at the Brotherhoodâ€™s Area 51 base we saw earlier in the season. Chaos is continuing there after Maximus took off with the Cold Fusion capsule. Anyway, Dane brings Quintus a scroll. He tells the scribe that Quintus the Unifier is no more. Instead, he is now Quintus the Destroyer and unrolls the scroll to reveal a blueprint for Liberty Prime.

We technically saw what appears to be Liberty Prime earlier this season in a photo featuring Mr. Houseâ€™s body double. But this is the giant democracy-defending robotâ€™s first real appearance in the show. Or, well, he appears as a blueprint schematic. Close enough.

This seems to be a new version of the big robot, named Liberty Prime Alpha, and is different from the mech that first appeared in Fallout 3 and later in Fallout 4. Iâ€™m not yet convinced this ragtag chapter of the Brotherhood of Steel is going to be able to create its own Liberty Prime. Perhaps itâ€™s buried away in Area 51? Weâ€™ll have to wait until season three to find out.

item.title: Ashes Of Creation Dev Details $3.2 Million Kickstarter Studioâ€™s Shocking Collapse: â€˜None Of Us Are Receiving Our Final Paychecksâ€™
item.content:encoded:
On January 29, Ashes of Creation maker Intrepid Studios was promising big updates to the recently launched, long-awaited fantasy Steam MMO. Less than a week later, the game has been review-bombed, removed from Valveâ€™s storefront, and seen all of its developers suddenly fired, according to a new post from the studioâ€™s communications director.

â€œI waited until today to share this because I wanted to be sure I was communicating from a place of clarity,â€ Intrepid Studios head of marketing Margaret Krohn wrote on X on Tuesday. â€œIntrepid Studios has shut down in a way that I did not expect. What I can share is what I experienced. On January 28, toward the end of the workday, I was informed that we would be laying off 100 developers. I was devastated â€“ these are hardworking people who were going to lose their jobs. Still, I believed it was something we could face together and find a path forward from.â€

I waited until today to share this because I wanted to be sure I was communicating from a place of clarity.

Intrepid Studios has shut down in a way that I did not expect. What I can share is what I experienced.

On January 28, toward the end of the workday, I was informed thatâ€¦

That was the day before an unsigned â€œdirectorâ€™s letterâ€ was posted to Ashes of Creationâ€˜s players promising a February 13 update on the gameâ€™s roadmap for the first few months of 2026. But according to Krohn, the mass firings at the studio were already moving forward. She said she received confirmation of which members of her team would be laid off by the end of day on January 29, and the remaining employees began working on â€œways to move forwardâ€ the following day. But by January 31, it became clear that no one at the studio was safe. 

â€œOn January 31, we were all informed via a confusing email that we would be laid off, along with a WARN notice,â€ she wrote. â€œIt is still shocking. The entire studio gathered to try to understand what had happened and what it meant for our future. In the end, none of us are receiving our final paychecks, the 60 days notice and pay outlined under the WARN Act, PTO payouts, or other compensation owed.â€

Thatâ€™s the same day that Ashes of Creation director Steven Sharif announced on Discord he was no longer in control of the company and was resigning in protest. â€œI can make a limited statement in my personal capacity and not on behalf of the company, regarding the situation,â€ he wrote on January 31. â€œControl of the company shifted away from me, and the Board began directing actions that I could not ethically agree with or carry out. As a result, I chose to resign in protest rather than lend my name or authority to decisions I could not ethically support.â€

That was the first public mention of the turmoil Intrepid was facing and it immediately ricocheted across Steam, where Ashes of Creation entered Early Access back in December, and Kickstarter, where backers raised $3.2 million to bring the MMORPG to market starting way back in 2017. The game was quickly review-bombed on Valveâ€™s storefront with warnings to other players to stay away of what soon might become a dead game, while backers on Kickstarter demanded refunds over the game never hitting a proper 1.0 launch. Itâ€™s since been removed from sale completely on Steam. 

â€œWhat matters most to me now are the people â€“ both the players and developers,â€ Krohn wrote today. â€œTo the players: the entire development team was working extremely hard, pulling long hours, and wishes with all our hearts that we could give you Ashes of Creation. There are no words that fully express how sorry we are that this journey ended this way. You should pursue a refund, you deserve it. To my colleagues: this team is truly a family. The culture we built together is something I have never experienced anywhere else. In the midst of heartbreak and uncertainty, we have come together to review resumes, help with portfolios, share job leads, and support one another emotionally.â€

As of now, itâ€™s unclear who remains in control of Intrepid Studios as a company, which is based out of San Diego, or what will happen to Ashes of Creation, whose potential for a comeback seems increasingly unlikely. Who funded the gameâ€™s development? How did the studioâ€™s finances suddenly get wiped out overnight? And what recourse do developers who worked on it have to be made whole? Kotaku tried reaching out to the studioâ€™s email address but we havenâ€™t heard back. Sharif declined to comment before clearing it with his legal counsel.

When we reached out to Krohn she responded with the following: â€œI made my statement. I canâ€™t really talk more than that, I think I might have even said too much as is, but people need to know what happened.â€

item.title: Next-Gen Xbox On Track For 2027 Launch Says AMD CEO
item.content:encoded:
Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) CEO Lisa Su shared some interesting information about two upcoming video game devices, Valveâ€™s Steam Machine and Xboxâ€™s next-gen console, both of which are powered by her companyâ€™s chips.

As reported by Gamesbeat on February 3, Su shared some new info about when to expect Valveâ€™s upcoming console-like PC gaming box, the Steam Machine, and further teased a possible launch window for Microsoftâ€™s previously confirmed-to-be-in-development next-generation Xbox.

â€œFrom a product standpoint, Valve is on track to begin shipping its AMD-powered Steam Machine early this year,â€ claimed Su in prepared remarks ahead of a financial call.  â€œAnd development of Microsoftâ€™s next-gen Xbox featuring an AMD semi-custom [System on Chip] is progressing well to support a launch in 2027.â€

This isnâ€™t a confirmation that the next Xbox will launch in 2027, but Su did point out that both the PS5 and Xbox Series X/S will be entering their seventh year on the market at that point, and thatâ€™s a good time for a refresh.

Valveâ€™s Steam Machine has a confirmed release date of 2026, but nothing any more specific. Valve says the Steam hardware family will expand in early 2026, but didnâ€™t specify if that was all three recently announced devices, just one, or some other combo like the VR headset and new controller. Suâ€™s comments seem to indicate that Valve could start selling and shipping Steam Machines to customers within the next few months. Meanwhile, weâ€™ve known for some time that Microsoft is trying to get the next Xbox out around 2027 or possibly 2028. Microsoft execs have also teased that the next-gen Xbox will be a â€œvery premium, very high-endâ€ device, so it doesnâ€™t sound cheap.

The next generation of game consoles will be expensive

While Su didnâ€™t talk about prices, itâ€™s pretty clear to anyone paying attention that any video game consoles or console-like devices arriving in the near future are going to cost quite a bit. President Trumpâ€™s tariffs have led to increased prices on many goods made overseas. Meanwhile, AI hyperscalers and tech giants are scooping up more and more PC parts, like RAM and GPUs, to help build out massive AI data centers. This has led to memory prices skyrocketing, and Nvidia is even reportedly looking to start making old GPUs again as the parts needed to make newer cards are routed toward making high-end cards for data centers.

Existing consoles, like the Switch 2 and Xbox Series X/S, could also see price increases in the future due to memory shortages and the rising cost of PC parts. Even AMDâ€™s cheaper GPUs are reportedly going to see price increases. Meanwhile, when weâ€™ve seen new gaming-adjacent tech launch in the last 12 months, the prices have been high, as in the case of Xbox and ROGâ€™s handheld PC which costs $1,000. And it looks like the Steam Machine will possibly cost $800 to $1000 or more when it launches later this year.

What does all of this mean for the PlayStation 6 and next Xbox? It means you probably need to start saving now if you want to afford one of these devices when they launch in the next 24 months or so. And maybe be prepared to go without one for a while, as itâ€™s likely there will be shortages for a long time following either consoleâ€™s future launch.

item.title: GTA 6 Doesnâ€™t Mean The End Of GTA Online: â€˜Weâ€™ll Continue To Support Itâ€™
item.content:encoded:
During todayâ€™s Take-Two Interactive quarterly financial call, the CEO of Rockstarâ€™s parent company was asked about the future of Grand Theft Auto Online after the release of Grand Theft Auto 6 in November. And he seemed pretty confident that the popular multiplayer game would keep receiving updates into 2027.

GTA Online first launched all the way back in October 2013 on Xbox 360 and PS3. It has since received hundreds of updates and expansions and been ported to many other consoles, where it continues to be incredibly popular and makes Take-Two a lot of money. So itâ€™s not surprising that Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick confirmed the gravy train isnâ€™t likely to shut down after GTA 6â€˜s multiplayer mode arrives, presumably, later this year.

â€œLook, Rockstar Games is the locus of information about, you know, where the titles go content and marketing, and generally, we have a pretty light touch when we talk about the labelâ€™s creative activities,â€ said Zelnick during Tuesdayâ€™s earnings call. â€œAt the same time, I have every reason to believe weâ€™ll continue to support GTA Online. Thereâ€™s a great community that loves it, that stays engaged. And again in this quarter, Rockstar has shown that when you deliver great additional content, despite how long [GTA Online] has been at market, people show up.â€

Back in 2025, Zelnick told IGN that Take-Two supports games as long as people are still playing them.

â€œAs an example, we launched NBA 2K Online in China, I think originally in 2012, if Iâ€™m not mistaken,â€ Zelnick told the outlet last year. â€œAnd then we launched NBA 2K Online 2 in China in 2017. If Iâ€™m not mistaken. We did not sunset Online 1. They both are still in the market, and they serve consumers, and theyâ€™re alive, and we have this massive audience. So weâ€™ve shown a willingness to support legacy titles when a community wants to be engaged with them.â€

That last part is key. Take-Two and Rockstar Games are more than happy to keep making content and updating old games, as long as there are enough people playing those games and spending money in them to financially justify it. And, at least for now, GTA Online definitely seems to qualify; it saw a 27-percent increase in consumer spending last quarter, according to Take-Two. When you have a money-printing machine, well, itâ€™s hard to convince anybody to turn it off.

item.title: Cyberpunk 2 Director Explains Why First-Person Was Perfect For The Original RPG: â€˜Youâ€™re A Mind Trapped In A Decaying Bodyâ€™
item.content:encoded:
When Cyberpunk 2077â€™s first-person perspective was revealed back in 2018, quite a few fans were worried. For CD Projekt Red enthusiasts who were used to staring at the back of Geraltâ€™s gorgeous little ponytail all day in The Witcher 3 and for others who just wanted to be able to see their painstaking customizations of protagonist V, the decision sparked its fair share of skepticism. However, it ended up working out pretty well, and now one of the gameâ€™s leads has taken to social media to explain why.

On Sunday, Igor SarzyÅ„ski, who worked as Cyberpunk 2077â€™s Cinematic Director before being bumped up to Creative Director for Cyberpunk 2, elaborated on the teamâ€™s decision to use a first-person perspective in 2077 via a thread on Bluesky.

â€œPurely from narrative design pov I think subjective FPP [first-person perspective] works well with â€˜77 story, genre and world. Youâ€™re a mind trapped in a decaying body with only means of leaving it being through technological consciousness processing,â€ he wrote (thanks, Games Radar).

Purely from narrative design pov I think subjective FPP works well with '77 story, genre and world. You're a mind trapped in a decaying body with only means of leaving it being through technological consciousness processing (cyberspace; soulkiller; projection into external devices; braindaces)

â€” igor.sarzynski (@srznsk.bsky.social) 2026-02-01T17:04:19.982Z

SarzyÅ„ski went on to elaborate on the role the perspective plays in our experience of a gameâ€™s story. Third-person perspective, he feels, â€œis better for more defined characters â€“ Geralt, Kratos, Ellie â€“ where you play-replay someone elseâ€™s story. FPP lends itself to more avatar-like player characters. V exists somewhere in the middle of this spectrum but for reasons stated above ^ i feel FPP was better for â€˜77.â€

He also added that the camera lets the gameâ€™s visions of â€œdigital ghostâ€ Johnny Silverhand, which he described as a â€œthing existing only in your subjective perception â€“ rather than both of you being seen equally by an external, objective TPP cam,â€ feel more immersive.

SarzyÅ„ski clarified that his comments arenâ€™t meant as a hint at the perspective that will be used in Cyberpunk 2, or anything else about the game for that matter. â€œIt might be a play-doh stop-motion RTS for all we know,â€ he joked. Itâ€™ll likely be a long time until we hear more news about Cyberpunk 2, but Iâ€™m just happy to hear from one of its leads. Itâ€™s always neat to hear about the thinking behind a design decision, especially at a massive studio that could, if it wanted to, be a lot more cagey about its development process.

Cyberpunk 2077â€™s sequel is still a ways away, but we do know that itâ€™ll be set in Night City once again, alongside a second city thatâ€™s â€œlike Chicago gone wrong.â€ CD Projekt Red also apparently began toying with some form of online multiplayer for the game shortly after it moved into pre-production last year, but itâ€™s unclear if thatâ€™ll even be implemented.

item.title: No, GTA 6 Isnâ€™t Skipping Physical Discs At Launch
item.content:encoded:
A strange rumor that popped up online last month claimed that, to avoid early leaks, Rockstar Games and Take-Two Interactive were going to delay the physical release of Grand Theft Auto 6 and the game would only launch digitally. Thatâ€™s not the case.

On February 3, as part of Take-Twoâ€™s Q3 fiscal results, the companyâ€™s longtime CEO Strauss Zelnick told Variety bluntly that the online rumors swirling around GTA 6â€˜s physical launch were nothing to worry about.

â€œThatâ€™s not the plan,â€ Zelnick told the outlet.

This odd rumor popped up in January after a Polish site reported that a Rockstar insider had heard that GTA 6â€²s physical and digital releases could be split up. Once the rumor popped up in January, it quickly spread and was reported by sites like Dexerto and was posted across places like Reddit, Twitter, YouTube, and Facebook. Here is the original, now debunked, claim:

â€œWe are getting more and more information that the box version will not be released simultaneously with the digital version to prevent leaks.â€

However, Kotaku was unable to verify the rumor with any of its sources. And to be honest, it always seemed odd, especially when you consider digital games have leaked via pre-loads. In fact, that happened with GTA V over a decade ago. And now that Zelnick has weighed in officially to call the rumor false, hopefully thatâ€™s the end of it. Now, GTA fans can go back to figuring out the SPF rating of an NPCâ€™s sunscreen via wild math and trailer screenshots.
